Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hf-Isotopes as Tracers of Highly Depleted Oceanic Mantle
Award.AbstractNarration: Volcanic activity on mid-ocean ridges constitutes one of the largest scale and most important chemical differentiation processes on earth. Magmas, created from the selective melting of Earth's mantle, bring some elements and elemental ratios to Earth's surface and leave others behind as residues in Earth's mantle. Of all the potential geochemical tracers examined to date, Hafnium (Hf) and Neodymium (Nd) appear to be the most powerful in helping us understand not only the chemical evolution of the mantle but also the ages and process of melt segregation and mid-ocean ridge volcanism. This research will use samples of abyssal peridotite from various mid-ocean ridges, emphasizing samples from the recently discovered ultra-slow spreading Gakkel Ridge in the Arctic, where mantle rocks outcrop on the seafloor. It will focus on determining the fraction of the mantle source that melts to form the vast majority of volcanic rocks erupted on the seafloor. To make this determination, trace elements and Hf and Nd isotopes will be measured, with the Hf isotopes illuminating the melting process and Nd providing age constraints. This work complements, but does not overlap with, a geochemical study of Gakkel abyssal peridotites. Broader impacts of the work include student training in state-of-the art geochemical analytical techniques and engaging high school students and their teachers in the research. It will also involve the high school participants in the laboratory and its activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaborative effort between the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and Florida State University to look at the isotopic composition of mantle peridotites dredged from heavily faulted regions of the oceans, where the crust is thin enough to expose the underlying mantle layer.  The mantle extends from below the crust (0-7 km thick in the oceans) down to the core-mantle boundary ~3,000 km, and is the source of the magmas that erupt onto the seafloor, and are emplaced below the lavas to form the ocean crust.  Here we attempted to link the mantle rocks and the basalts through analysis of their Nd-isotopic composition.  The goal here is to understand how variable in composition the Earth shallow mantle is, and the extent to which this is reflected in the composition of the magmas that erupt from it.  We found that the mantle rocks show greater compositional variability than the basalts, which is interepreted to mean that as the mantle melts, magmas from different regions mix together as they migrate up through the mantle, homogenizing their composition. A major goal of research into the composition and evolution of the mantle, which is generally inaccessible, except for its shallowest layers that are locally exposed on the seafloor, is to understand its composition, how this varies, and how this reflects the processes that occur there over geologic time.  Our results support the idea that the mantle varies in composition both locally and regionally between different parts of the globe due to plate tectonic cycles, which cause the crust and shallow mantle to be mixed back into the deep mantle, modifying its compostion through time.  Since this process is not uniform over the globe, but specific to different regions, this has caused one mantle region to significantly vary from the next, and that locally, mixing is not efficient enough to fully homogenize the mantle. There are human consequences to this, in that the mantle is the source of the magmas that erupt in the continents as well as the oceans, and the magmas vary with the composition of the mantle source, and hence in the type of volcanism and the degree to which they represent hazard to human life.  In addition, volcanism is a major source of green house gases that affect climate change, and the pattern of their eruption through time and in space is one of the factors that must be considered in the global carbon cycle.
